Translation: Intended: ‘a woman proud of her work’
Comment: Transitive adjective phrases are confined to predicate position, and may not occur inside a noun phrase (Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina_, p.138).

Translation: a woman who is proud of her work
Comment: When used to modify a noun phrase, transitive adjective phrases must be in the forms of relative clauses(Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina_2003, p.138).
"Some modifiers denoting nationality can precede or (occasionally) follow the head noun
column11: in that it is explicitly a combining form and hence must precede the head."

Translation: She is proud of her work.
Comment: Such transitive adjective phrases are confined to predicate position, and may not occur inside a noun phrase (Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina_2003, p.138).

The perfective participle of a verb may function as an ordinary lexical adjective. In Eastern varieties (only), such articples can alsp take modifiers and complements and can used in a prenominal position (Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina_2003, p. 142).

Translation: the girl I gave flowers to

Parameter: eus_V_attr eus_V_N eus_VP_N eus_V_lnk eus_V_lnk_obl eus_V_attr_agr
Translation: 'the apples that you bought in the market

Comment: nationality modifier can form a complex modifier with the suffix =ko
suffix =ko can be added to simple lexical adverbs such as 'atzo' (yesterday)
suffix =ko can be added to morphologically complex adverbs such as 'hitzez hitz' (word for word)
suffix =ko can be added to an NP marked for any local case such as 'mendietan' (in the mountains)
suffix =ko can be added to a postpositional phrase such as 'losta gabe' (without shame)

Translation: the season when doves pass over
Comment: suffix =ko can be added to a finite adverbial clause (only in certain circumstances, notably with temporal clauses, since most other formations would be senseless)

Translation: the ring bought yesterday in Bilbao
Comment: suffix =ko can be added in an adverbial participle in -ta or -(r)ik (together with its arguments and adjuncts)
